metadata.instructions:
Data files description:

README.txt describes the datasets and their headers

Sites information.csv has the following headers:
(1)	Sites code: e.g. A1 to A15, B1 to B20, C1 to C4, D1 to D4.
(2)	Longitude: longitude coordinates.
(3)	Latitude: latitude coordinates.
(4)	Distance: in meters between plots (sensors) in each site.
(5)	Landcover type in plot A:  bare ground (BG), alpine meadow (AM), alpine swamp meadow (ASM), and alpine steppe (AS).
(6)	Landcover type in plot B:  Similar description to header (5)
(7)	Elevation in meters above sea level.
(8)	Zone: local scale (A), landscape scale (C), elevational transect (B).

Data file GST_3h_h00.csv: GST values every 3 hours starting from 00:00 AM.
Data file GST_3h_h03.csv: GST values every 3 hours starting from 03:00 AM.
(1)	Date/Time: UTC Date and Time format YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS (Year-Month-Day Hour:Minute:Second).
(2)	Observational GST values at each site in °C: missing values (NA). Example of site code: A1A (site A1 plot A), C3B (site C3 plot B), D2B (site D2 plot B).

background: Known as the “roof of the world” or the core of the Third Pole, the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau (QTP) is the largest and highest plateau in the world due to its complex terrains and an average elevation of 4000 m a.s.l. The QTP is highly sensitive to climate change, and the plateau ecosystems are vulnerable to climate warming because about 55 % of the plateau surface is underlain by seasonally frozen ground (SFG), and 40 % to 46 % by permafrost. In most locations in the world, permafrost monitoring sites have revealed an increasing trend in permafrost temperature. On the QTP, the temperature of permafrost at 6 m in depth increased by 0.43 °C from 1996 to 2006 and at an average rate of 0.02 °C yr −1 from 2006 to 2010. At about half of the permafrost monitoring sites on the QTP, permafrost is warm (> −1 °C), while for about two-thirds of sites permafrost is warmer than −1.5 °C. Earth system models predicted that permafrost thicker than 10 m covers 36 % of the QTP and permafrost will continue to thin at annual rates of up to 21 cm yr−1 under various climate change scenarios. Several models for permafrost distribution have been built and applied for the QTP but with significant across-model differences in model accuracies as compared to in situ observations. However, the borehole networks for permafrost monitoring are sparse on the QTP, which are concentrated solely along the main infrastructure lines; thus, the monitoring results cannot properly validate the permafrost models at diverse spatiotemporal scales. Therefore, the observational networks of ground surface temperature (GST) could represent a solution to better evaluate these models in rugged terrains and at a finer spatial resolution. GST is essential for understanding the surface energy dynamics and flows, water cycles, ecology, ecohydrology, and climate change impacts in the Earth critical zone, especially in cold regions. GST directly impacts the chemical and biological processes of carbon and nitrogen in the soil and establishes the quality of soil resources. GST has been largely used to understand the thermal regimes in the periglacial environment, to understand the hydrothermal and biogeochemical dynamics of the active layer, and to delineate the distribution of SFG and permafrost. GST influences surface water cycles and vegetation growth and can be used as the upper boundary condition for simulating the thermal state of permafrost and active layer thickness. Although GST has been manually measured since the 1950s through the network of the China Meteorological Administration, these earlier measurements were inconsistent with the recent automatic measurements. Furthermore, the manual protocol of historical measurements was highly biased by the presence of snow cover. A high spatial variability of the mean annual GST (MAGST) has been reported in alpine regions due to the large heterogeneity of surface covers, topography, and snow cover conditions. However, few studies compared the variability of MAGST at a small scale, such as 0.5 km2 in the Scandinavian Mountains and Arctic Canada, or distances < 50 m in the Swiss Alps or up to 100 m in southern Norway. Recently, variations in MAGST have also been assessed at small scales on the northeastern QTP, such as 3.5 km2 and at distances from 2 to 16 m and areas of 2 to 50 km 2. Unfortunately, GSTs are still scantly monitored in mountains, while studies have revealed their importance in the cryosphere, ecosystem monitoring, and hazard mitigation. Nevertheless, we lack systematic monitoring of GSTs and an understanding of their fine-scale variability in time and space.
research objective: The objectives of this paper are the following: (1) present the GST monitoring design from fine scale (2 to 16 m distance) to local and landscape scales (2 and 50 km2) and across an 800 m elevational transect, (2) evaluate the data quality, (3) identify the fine-scale variability of GST under similar and different land-cover conditions, and (4) assess the possibility to identify permafrost occurrence based on GST.
challenges: The borehole networks for permafrost monitoring are sparse on the QTP, which are concentrated solely along the main infrastructure lines; thus, the monitoring results cannot properly validate the permafrost models at diverse spatiotemporal scales. Nevertheless, we lack systematic monitoring of GSTs and an understanding of their fine-scale variability in time and space.
methods: GST was measured every 3 h using 72 iButton temperature loggers (DS1922L) at 39 sites from 2019 to 2020. GST was monitored along an 800 m elevational transect, at local and landscape scales (2 and 50 km 2), and at a fine scale at distances of up to 16 m. All sensors were sealed in pouches to enhance their waterproofing and installed at a depth of approximately 5 cm. The measurement period was 1 hydrological year from 1 August 2019 to 31 July 2020, and the temperature was recorded once every 3 h. The raw GST data were processed by adapting the R scripts developed by Way and Lewkowicz (2018) for automated manipulation of data from the iButton loggers. Several statistical parameters were computed to compare the GST from the two plots of each site: the Pearson correlation coefficient (r), the absolute differences in daily GST and MAGST, and the coefficient of determination (R2) from linear regression models. From 11 plots, soil samples were collected for grain size and water content analysis. Samples were weighed before and after being dried at 105 °C for 16 h to determine the water content. The coarse texture represented by gravel (> 2 mm) was quantified by sieving, while the fine texture ( < 2 mm) representing sand, silt, and clay was measured with a Malvern Mastersizer-2000 laser diffraction particle size analyzer.
dataset: GST was measured every 3 h using 72 iButton temperature loggers (DS1922L) at 39 sites from 2019 to 2020. The datasets are openly available from the National Tibetan Plateau/Third Pole Environment Data Center (https://doi.org/10.11888/Cryos.tpdc.272945, ¸ Serban and Jin, 2022).
findings: The sites with similar land covers in both plots mainly presented an intra-plot difference of daily GST below 2 °C. The intra-plot variability in MAGST was< 0.5 °C (similar land cover in both plots) and increased to 1–2 °C when the bare ground was compared to vegetated plots. The negative MAGST was associated with an FN> 0.5, indicating the probable presence of permafrost, and this was further validated by borehole measurements. Sites with a MAGST < −1 °C corresponded well with the stable permafrost, while sites with a MAGST > 1 °C matched the areas of SFG.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'ground surface temperature (GST)' in permafrost research?
Definition.Answer: Ground surface temperature (GST) is essential for understanding the surface energy dynamics and flows, water cycles, ecology, ecohydrology, and climate change impacts in the Earth critical zone, especially in cold regions. GST directly impacts the chemical and biological processes of carbon and nitrogen in the soil and establishes the quality of soil resources. GST has been largely used to understand the thermal regimes in the periglacial environment, to understand the hydrothermal and biogeochemical dynamics of the active layer, and to delineate the distribution of seasonally frozen ground (SFG) and permafrost. GST influences surface water cycles and vegetation growth and can be used as the upper boundary condition for simulating the thermal state of permafrost and active layer thickness.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with the 'borehole networks for permafrost monitoring' on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Definition.Answer: The borehole networks for permafrost monitoring on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau are sparse and concentrated solely along the main infrastructure lines. This spatial limitation means the monitoring results cannot properly validate permafrost models at diverse spatiotemporal scales, which highlights the need for systematic monitoring of ground surface temperatures to address the fine-scale variability in time and space.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for ground surface temperature (GST) on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau compare to traditional permafrost monitoring methods?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection methods for GST on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau involve using iButton temperature loggers placed at various scales and depths, providing high-resolution temporal data every 3 hours. In contrast, traditional permafrost monitoring methods rely on borehole networks, which are sparse and primarily located along main infrastructure lines, limiting their ability to validate permafrost models at diverse spatiotemporal scales.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data quality evaluation between GST data collected at fine scales versus landscape scales?
Comparison.Answer: The GST data collected at fine scales (2 to 16 m distances) show an intra-plot variability in MAGST of less than 0.5 °C for similar land covers, while variability increases to 1-2 °C when comparing bare ground to vegetated plots. This fine-scale data allows for a detailed assessment of permafrost occurrence compared to broader landscape scales, where data might not capture such localized variability effectively.

Comparison.Question: How does the variability of mean annual ground surface temperature (MAGST) in alpine regions compare across different geographic locations such as the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, Scandinavian Mountains, and Swiss Alps?
Comparison.Answer: The variability of MAGST in alpine regions is influenced by heterogeneity in surface covers, topography, and snow cover conditions. In the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, variations have been assessed at small scales, such as within areas of 3.5 km² and distances from 2 to 16 m. Comparatively, similar studies in the Scandinavian Mountains and Swiss Alps report small-scale variability, yet the specific ranges and impacts of geographic and environmental factors can differ across these regions.

Interpretation.Question: How do the challenges of sparse borehole networks for permafrost monitoring influence the development of alternative data collection methods for GST on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges posed by sparse borehole networks for permafrost monitoring have influenced the development of alternative data collection methods such as the observational networks of GST. These networks provide data at diverse spatiotemporal scales and can better evaluate permafrost models in rugged terrains at a finer spatial resolution, thus offering a more comprehensive understanding of thermal dynamics in the region.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways do the methodologies for processing GST data, such as using R scripts, enhance the reliability and precision of temperature measurements in environmental studies?
Interpretation.Answer: Methodologies for processing GST data, such as using R scripts for automated data manipulation, enhance the reliability and precision of temperature measurements by allowing for consistent and systematic analysis. This approach enables researchers to compute several statistical parameters, such as the Pearson correlation coefficient and the coefficient of determination, which help in comparing GST data across different sites and improving the accuracy of the findings.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a challenge in validating permafrost models on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenge in validating permafrost models on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau stems from the sparse distribution of borehole networks, which are primarily concentrated along main infrastructure lines. This limited distribution prevents a thorough validation across diverse terrains and scales, necessitating alternative observational networks like GST monitoring to provide the necessary data for model validation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the exclusion of certain sensors from GST datasets in this region?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Sensors may be excluded from GST datasets due to malfunctions or biased data, which could arise from issues such as improper installation, environmental conditions affecting sensor performance, or technical failures. Ensuring the quality of GST data requires rigorous quality checks to identify and exclude compromised sensors, maintaining the integrity of the dataset.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind designing a ground surface temperature monitoring network across different scales on the northeastern Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives include presenting the GST monitoring design from fine scale to landscape scales, evaluating data quality, identifying fine-scale variability of GST under different land-cover conditions, and assessing the potential to identify permafrost occurrence based on GST.

Goal Orientation.Question: What challenges are addressed by implementing systematic ground surface temperature monitoring in the complex terrains of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Systematic GST monitoring addresses the challenges posed by sparse permafrost borehole networks, which are concentrated along main infrastructure lines and unable to validate permafrost models at diverse spatiotemporal scales. It helps in better evaluating models in rugged terrains at finer spatial resolutions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What is the process for deploying temperature loggers to ensure accurate and consistent ground surface temperature measurement across various scales on the northeastern Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Temperature loggers, specifically iButton temperature loggers (DS1922L), were deployed at 39 sites covering different scales: an 800-m elevational transect, landscape scale, local scale, and fine scale. The sensors were placed below four different landcover types at approximately 5 cm depth to avoid solar heating. The loggers were sealed in pouches to enhance waterproofing and were set to record temperature every 3 hours for one hydrological year.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are data quality checks conducted on ground surface temperature measurements to ensure reliability and validity in the context of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau study?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data quality checks involved excluding 11 out of 83 sensors due to malfunctions or biased data. The raw GST data were processed using adapted R scripts for automated data manipulation, and statistical parameters such as the Pearson correlation coefficient, absolute differences in daily GST and MAGST, and the coefficient of determination from linear regression models were computed to assess data reliability.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the fine-scale variability of ground surface temperature to be captured across different landcover types on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The use of iButton temperature loggers (DS1922L) placed at a depth of approximately 5 cm allows for capturing fine-scale variability of ground surface temperature. These sensors were deployed at various scales from an 800 m elevational transect to fine scales, with measurements taken every 3 hours over one hydrological year.

Enablement.Question: How do statistical analyses enable the assessment of data quality in ground surface temperature datasets?
Enablement.Answer: Statistical analyses such as computing the Pearson correlation coefficient, absolute differences in daily GST and MAGST, and the coefficient of determination (R2) from linear regression models allow for assessing the data quality and variability of ground surface temperature datasets at different plots and sites.

Enablement.Question: What conditions enable the identification of permafrost occurrence based on ground surface temperature measurements?
Enablement.Answer: The identification of permafrost occurrence is enabled by the observed negative MAGST associated with an FN> 0.5. This approach was validated through borehole measurements, where sites with MAGST < −1 °C corresponded well with stable permafrost, while sites with MAGST > 1 °C matched areas of seasonally frozen ground.

Expectation.Question: Why might researchers expect challenges in validating permafrost models at diverse spatiotemporal scales when using observational networks of ground surface temperature (GST)?
Expectation.Answer: The challenges arise because borehole networks for permafrost monitoring are sparse and concentrated solely along main infrastructure lines. This limits the ability to properly validate permafrost models across varying scales, which can be addressed by using GST observational networks to better evaluate models in rugged terrains and at finer spatial resolutions.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected benefits of using a multiscale GST monitoring design in understanding the fine-scale variability of ground surface temperature?
Expectation.Answer: A multiscale GST monitoring design allows researchers to capture detailed data across fine scales (2 to 16 m distances) to broader local and landscape scales (2 and 50 km²), as well as along elevational transects. This approach is anticipated to reveal the fine-scale variability of GST under similar and different land-cover conditions, which is crucial for identifying permafrost occurrences and understanding thermal regimes and ecological impacts.

Expectation.Question: Why might small-scale variability in mean annual ground surface temperature (MAGST) be expected to differ significantly in alpine regions?
Expectation.Answer: The high spatial variability in MAGST in alpine regions is expected due to the large heterogeneity of surface covers, topography, and snow cover conditions. This variability can be significant even at small scales, which makes systematic monitoring and comparison of MAGST across different scales essential for understanding local thermal dynamics and ecological processes.

Judgmental.Question: What are the main challenges in ensuring the accuracy and reliability of ground surface temperature data collected using iButton temperature loggers in remote and harsh environments?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges include ensuring the waterproofing and proper installation of sensors at the correct depth to avoid solar heating effects. Additionally, data quality must be maintained through regular calibration and exclusion of malfunctioning sensors. The variability in landcover, snow cover, and topography also pose challenges to accurately capturing GST data, requiring careful design of monitoring networks and data processing.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the challenges faced in validating permafrost models across diverse spatiotemporal scales using observational networks.
Assertion.Answer: A significant challenge is the sparse distribution of borehole networks for permafrost monitoring, which are mainly concentrated along infrastructure lines, limiting model validation. GST observational networks offer a solution by providing data across various scales and terrains, enhancing model evaluation with finer spatial resolution data.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how datasets on ground surface temperature can be expanded or refined for better understanding of permafrost dynamics.
Assertion.Answer: Datasets can be expanded by increasing the density of sensors across different terrains and landcover types, enhancing the fine-scale variability understanding. Additionally, combining GST data with other environmental variables, such as soil moisture and texture, can provide a more comprehensive understanding of permafrost dynamics and improve model predictions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze and describe the data collection methods used for monitoring ground surface temperature under different land cover types and scales on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: Ground surface temperature (GST) was measured using 72 iButton temperature loggers (DS1922L) at 39 sites from 2019 to 2020. The monitoring network was designed to cover various scales: an 800-m elevational transect, landscape scale, local scale, and fine scale. Sensors were placed below four different land cover types at approximately 5 cm depth. The temperature was recorded every 3 hours over one hydrological year. Data processing involved adapting R scripts for automatic data manipulation, and statistical parameters such as Pearson correlation coefficient and linear regression models were used to compare GST data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and discuss the challenges faced in collecting and validating permafrost temperature data on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, considering the existing monitoring networks.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include the sparse distribution of borehole networks for permafrost monitoring, concentrated mainly along infrastructure lines, which limits the ability to validate permafrost models at diverse spatiotemporal scales. There is also a lack of systematic monitoring and understanding of GST fine-scale variability. Historical manual measurements were inconsistent with recent automatic measurements, and snow cover biased earlier data. High spatial variability in mean annual GST due to surface cover heterogeneity, topography, and snow conditions also presents a challenge.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets available for further research on the thermal state of permafrost and active layer thickness in cold regions like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: The dataset of GST measured every 3 hours using iButton temperature loggers at 39 sites from 2019 to 2020 is openly available from the National Tibetan Plateau/Third Pole Environment Data Center. This dataset complements sparse observations of GST on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau and assists in identifying permafrost thaw patterns. Additionally, soil samples were collected for grain size and water content analysis, which could provide further insights into soil thermal properties related to permafrost and active layer dynamics.
